channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Here's how Trump and the GOP may try to weaken Obamacare
item.description: Republican control of the White House and Congress sets the stage for potentially seismic changes including curtailing Medicaid, weakening patient protections, and increasing premium costs for millions.
item.content:encoded:
Republican control of the White House and Congress sets the stage for potentially seismic changes including curtailing Medicaid, weakening patient protections, and increasing premium costs for millions.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Armour

item.title: Richer countries are starting to pay poorer ones for climate change damages
item.description: With climate-related disasters getting more extreme, richer countries are piloting ways to compensate developing nations, since they bear the least responsibility for causing climate change.
item.content:encoded:
With climate-related disasters getting more extreme, richer countries are piloting ways to compensate developing nations, since they bear the least responsibility for causing climate change.

(Image credit: AMOS GUMULIRA/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sommer

item.title: Most of the country shifted right in the 2024 presidential election
item.description: In 2020, President Biden won six of the seven closely watched states. This year, President-elect Donald Trump won all seven — plus he will got a majority of the popular vote.
item.content:encoded: In 2020, President Biden won six of the seven closely watched states. This year, President-elect Donald Trump won all seven — plus he will got a majority of the popular vote.
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro

item.title: Chinese vessel under investigation after 2 data cables found cut in the Baltic Sea
item.description: Germany's defense minister said damage to two data cables in the Baltic Sea appeared to be acts of sabotage. Several European countries have launched investigations.
item.content:encoded: Germany's defense minister said damage to two data cables in the Baltic Sea appeared to be acts of sabotage. Several European countries have launched investigations.
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: To hit deep inside Russia, Ukraine has built its own drones
item.description: President Biden has now given Ukraine permission to use U.S. ballistic missiles inside Russia. While it was waiting, Ukraine built its own drones that can strike far across the border.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden has now given Ukraine permission to use U.S. ballistic missiles inside Russia. While it was waiting, Ukraine built its own drones that can strike far across the border.

(Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: UConn's Geno Auriemma becomes the all-time winningest college basketball coach
item.description: Geno Auriemma has led the women Huskies to 11 championships and nearly two dozen Final Four appearances in his four decades as head coach.
item.content:encoded:
Geno Auriemma has led the women Huskies to 11 championships and nearly two dozen Final Four appearances in his four decades as head coach.

(Image credit: Jessica Hill)
item.dc:creator: Ayana Archie

item.title: A duct-taped banana sells for $6.2 million at an art auction
item.description: A piece of conceptual art consisting of a simple banana, duct-taped to a wall, sold for $6.2 million at an auction Wednesday, with the winning bid coming from a prominent cryptocurrency entrepreneur.
item.content:encoded:
Comedian during an auction preview at Sotheby's in New York on Nov. 11, 2024.'/>

A piece of conceptual art consisting of a simple banana, duct-taped to a wall, sold for $6.2 million at an auction Wednesday, with the winning bid coming from a prominent cryptocurrency entrepreneur.

(Image credit: Eduardo Munoz Alvarez)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: The Justice Department is trying to make Google sell its Chrome browser
item.description: If a judge orders Google to sell Chrome, it could dramatically upend the multibillion-dollar online search business.
item.content:encoded:
If a judge orders Google to sell Chrome, it could dramatically upend the multibillion-dollar online search business.

(Image credit: Matt Slocum)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: U.S. charges Indian billionaire with defrauding investors, hiding bribery scheme
item.description: One of the world's richest people has been indicted on charges he duped investors in a massive solar energy project in India by concealing that it was being facilitated by an alleged bribery scheme.
item.content:encoded:
One of the world's richest people has been indicted on charges he duped investors in a massive solar energy project in India by concealing that it was being facilitated by an alleged bribery scheme.

(Image credit: Ajit Solanki)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Witnesses say Israel is using sniper drones in Gaza and they're shooting civilians
item.description:
Last week British surgeon Nizam Mamode testified in front of a committee in the U.K. Parliament. Dr. Mamode had recently returned from working at a hospital in Central Gaza.

He told parliamentary members what he witnessed, including drones that would come down and "pick off civilians, children. And we had description after description. This is not, you know, an occasional thing. This was day after day after day."

For months, NPR has been collecting eyewitness accounts from Gaza that corroborate Dr. Mamode's testimony, saying the Israeli military has been using sniper drone technology and that they're not just shooting enemies, but also civilians.|

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Last week British surgeon Nizam Mamode testified in front of a committee in the U.K. Parliament. Dr. Mamode had recently returned from working at a hospital in Central Gaza.

He told parliamentary members what he witnessed, including drones that would come down and "pick off civilians, children. And we had description after description. This is not, you know, an occasional thing. This was day after day after day."

For months, NPR has been collecting eyewitness accounts from Gaza that corroborate Dr. Mamode's testimony, saying the Israeli military has been using sniper drone technology and that they're not just shooting enemies, but also civilians.|

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: EYAD BABA)
